channel.title: This land, this heritage, this people
channel.description:
This series traces in word and music the footprints of America, the turns we took, the tales we spread. Narratives, letters, diaries, and songs have beenÂ adapted from primary source materials by Professor Robert E. Gard, director of the Wisconsin Idea Theater. Features Professor Gard as well as guitarist-singer Kent Toepfer.,Series featuring readings from letters, diaries, books and narratives, interspersed with songs of the times. Features Prof. Robert Gard, director, Wisconsin Idea Theatre; and Kent Toepfer, guitarist-singer.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

image.title: This land, this heritage, this people

item.title: Jack London & Hoboes that Pass in t
item.description: Writer Jack London describes his experience riding the rails in his story Hoboes That Pass in the Night. Songs include You Wonder Why I'm a Hobo, The Gambler, and 900 Miles.
item.dc:creator: Gard, Robert Edward
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Mike Fink & the Ohio River
item.description: Mike Fink & the Ohio River. Narratives about the famous keel boater from a number of sources, including Col. Frank Triplett's Conquering the Wilderness, written in 1883; songs include The Lovely Ohio and Shawnee Town.
item.dc:creator: Gard, Robert Edward
item.dc:subject: United States--History--19th century

item.title: Chicago
item.description: This program features music composed between 1858 and 1892 and made available from the Chicago Historical Society archives.
item.dc:creator: Gard, Robert Edward
item.dc:subject: United States--History--19th century

item.title: The People of the Ozarks
item.description: The People of the Ozarks. Narrative from the works of folklorist Vance Randolph. Music includes Grandma's Advice, Way Down Yonder in the Paw-Paw Patch, and We're Coming, Arkansas.
item.dc:creator: Gard, Robert Edward
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century

item.title: Mark Twain and the Mississippi
item.description: Mark Twain and the Mississippi. Narratives from writings about the Mississippi from 1693 through Twain's works; also, various songs.
item.dc:creator: Gard, Robert Edward
item.dc:subject: Writing

item.title: J. Frank Dobie & Texas
item.description: Yarns that bring out human characteristics and illustrate customs and manners and social conditions are in a way as important historically as state papers. Moreover a yarn, if it's a good one has flavor and people have a right to enjoy the taste of their food as well as to be nourished by it. Narrative largely from J. Frank Dobie's The Flavor of Texas; songs include The Devil in Hell.
item.dc:creator: Gard, Robert Edward
item.dc:subject: U.S. Literature

item.title: The Lumbermen
item.description: This program features music recorded by Michigan lumberjacks recorded on discs around 1935.
item.dc:creator: Gard, Robert Edward
item.dc:subject: United States--History--20th century
